stem: An 84-year-old client with type 2 diabetes is admitted with profound dehydration and confusion. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute hyperglycemic crisis in an elderly client.
Background: Type 2 diabetes for 30 years. Recently treated for a respiratory infection.
Assessment: Client is stuporous; dry mucous membranes; skin tenting present.
Recommendation: Aggressive isotonic rehydration.

tabs.title: Metabolic Monitoring & Hydration Index
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Blood Glucose1,120 mg/dLExtreme Hyperglycemia
Serum Osmolality350 mOsm/kgSevere Hemoconcentration
Arterial pH7.36No Acidosis
Urine KetonesNegative to TraceNo Ketosis
Serum Bicarbonate24 mEq/LNormal base balance

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 82/48 mm Hg, HR 132 bpm, RR 18 breaths/min, T 100.4°F (38°C).

actionOptions.text: Administer 0.9% sodium chloride boluses until BP stabilizes.
Initiate IV regular insulin after starting fluid resuscitation.
Administer sodium bicarbonate IV for acidosis.

parameterOptions.text: Mental status and neurological assessments (seizure risk)
Hourly blood glucose and serum electrolytes
Serial arterial blood gas (ABG) for pH trends
Peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) every 4 hours

rationale.correct: This client is experiencing hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) (c2), which occurs primarily in clients with type 2 diabetes. Differentiating factors from DKA include: glucose much higher (>600 mg/dL), normal pH (no acidosis), and no ketones. Rehydration (a1) is the most critical step because the client is profoundly dehydrated. Insulin (a2) is given to lower the glucose but must follow fluids to prevent circulatory collapse. Monitoring neurological status (p1) is vital since rapid changes in osmolality can cause cerebral edema, and glucose (p2) must be tracked hourly.
clinicalPearls: HHS has a higher mortality rate than DKA because it affects older patients with more comorbidities.
The 'ketones' are negative in HHS because clients with type 2 diabetes still have enough endogenous insulin to suppress lipase and prevent ketone formation, but not enough to control glucose.
The number one cause of HHS is infection (UTI/pneumonia).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: HHS is not acidotic. If the pH is normal (7.35-7.45), do not give bicarbonate.

mnemonic.title: HHS Highlights
mnemonic.expansion: H-High Glucose (>600 mg/dL). H-Hydration (First priority). S-Stupor (Confusion).
